Issues.Title: Event handling intercepted
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug?

compiler

### Is this a regression?

Yes

### Description

I have something like this:

```
<input ... /> Pure text input, can be input or textarea

<image-upload (document:paste)="canPaste && handlePaste($event) ... />
```

This has been working fine for a long time. Recently (within a few weeks) it started to intercept event bubbling when `canPaste` is false. So `Ctrl+V` / `Right click + Paste` in text input stopped working, simply got ignored.

### Please provide a link to a minimal reproduction of the bug

https://stackblitz.com/edit/stackblitz-starters-izh8md?file=src%2Fmain.ts

### Please provide the exception or error you saw

```true
Pasting into the text input does nothing.
```


### Please provide the environment you discovered this bug in (run `ng version`)

```true
Angular CLI: 16.2.8
Node: 18.18.1
Package Manager: npm 9.8.1
OS: win32 x64

Angular: 16.2.11
... animations, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms
... language-service, localize, platform-browser
... platform-browser-dynamic, router, service-worker

Package                         Version
---------------------------------------------------------
@angular-devkit/architect       0.1602.8
@angular-devkit/build-angular   16.2.8
@angular-devkit/core            16.2.8
@angular-devkit/schematics      16.2.8
@angular/cdk                    16.2.10
@angular/cli                    16.2.8
@angular/material               16.2.10
@schematics/angular             16.2.8
rxjs                            7.8.1
typescript                      5.1.6
zone.js                         0.13.3
```


### Anything else?

Of course this can be worked around by moving the condition check into the `handlePaste` method.

I did an `ng update` after discovering the issue, so the real issue might be introduced a couple patch release earlier.

I hope this is not a case of Mandela Effect... Did it use to work, or not :) ??

Issues.Title: Update zone.md
Issues.Body:
Updated the "Setting up Zone.js" instructions to the latest convention from how the Angular CLI configures it.

https://angular.io/guide/zone#setting-up-zonejs

## PR Checklist
Please check if your PR fulfills the following requirements:

- [x] The commit message follows our guidelines: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md#commit
- [ ] Tests for the changes have been added (for bug fixes / features)
- [ ] Docs have been added / updated (for bug fixes / features)


## PR Type
What kind of change does this PR introduce?

<!-- Please check the one that applies to this PR using "x". -->

- [ ] Bugfix
- [ ] Feature
- [ ] Code style update (formatting, local variables)
- [ ] Refactoring (no functional changes, no api changes)
- [ ] Build related changes
- [ ] CI related changes
- [x] Documentation content changes
- [ ] angular.io application / infrastructure changes
- [ ] Other... Please describe:


## What is the current behavior?
<!-- Please describe the current behavior that you are modifying, or link to a relevant issue. -->

The current [Setting up Zone.js documentation](https://angular.io/guide/zone#setting-up-zonejs) is outdated and shows the previous way of how `zone.js` is setup when using the Angular CLI.

The docs say you must import `zone-flags` before you import `zone.js` in the `polyfills.ts`, but there is no longer a `polyfills.ts` file.

Current: 

`angular.json`:
```json
"polyfills": "src/polyfills.ts"
```

`src/polyfills.ts`:
```ts
import './zone-flags';
import 'zone.js/dist/zone';
```

Issue Number: N/A


## What is the new behavior?

The new behavior in the latest Angular CLI (when creating a new angular app via `$ ng new appname`), does not generate a `src/polyfills.ts` file, nor does the `polyfills` value point to that file in `angular.json`. Instead, it includes a reference to `zone.js` directly in the `angular.json` file, in a `polyfills` array.

To set or change settings from `zone.js`, you must add your `zone-flags.ts` in the `polyfills` array, before `zone.js`.

New: 

`angular.json`:
```json
"polyfills": [
    "src/zone-flags.ts",
    "zone.js"
  ]
```

## Does this PR introduce a breaking change?

- [ ] Yes
- [x] No


<!-- If this PR contains a breaking change, please describe the impact and migration path for existing applications below. -->


## Other information

Issues.Title: Validator is executed before pipes are run causing validation errors on correct data and correct regex.
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug?

forms

### Is this a regression?

No

### Description

When using (somewhat simplified, see stackblitz for an example that demonstrates it more elaborately)
```
<form [formGroup]="accountingFg">
   <input formControlName="amount" pattern="^-?\d{1,3}( \d{3})*(\.[0-9]{2})?$" [value]="accountingFg.get('amount')?.value.toString() | customPipe" />
</form>
```

Where the pipe manipulates the content to be according to a specific format, the validator runs before the pipe, which makes the validator validate a value that is not yet manipulated into the correct format (see stackblitz link).

As I see it, pipes and validators are an integral part of angular and it is not unreasonable to suggest that they should be run in such an order that the validation occurs after the value has been manipulated in the pipe, or am I at fault here?

![image (7)](https://github.com/angular/angular/assets/24667970/4e80056c-a856-411b-89da-743b9039d9a0)


### Please provide a link to a minimal reproduction of the bug

https://stackblitz.com/edit/stackblitz-starters-umgsce?devToolsHeight=33&file=src%2Fmain.ts

### Please provide the exception or error you saw

```true
pattern:
{requiredPattern: '/^-?\\d{1,3}( \\d{3})*(\\.[0-9]{2})?$/', actualValue: '5 5555'}
actualValue:
'5 5555'
requiredPattern:
'/^-?\\d{1,3}( \\d{3})*(\\.[0-9]{2})?$/'
---
The pipe will correct the format of the digits to the correct format: 55 555. However, the validator runs before the pipe.
```


### Please provide the environment you discovered this bug in (run `ng version`)

```true
Angular CLI: 16.2.3
Node: 18.16.0
Package Manager: npm 9.5.1
OS: linux x64

Angular: 16.2.6
... animations, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms
... platform-browser, platform-browser-dynamic, router

Package                         Version
---------------------------------------------------------
@angular-devkit/architect       0.1602.3
@angular-devkit/build-angular   16.2.3
@angular-devkit/core            16.2.3
@angular-devkit/schematics      16.2.3
@angular/cdk                    16.2.5
@angular/cli                    16.2.3
@angular/material               16.2.5
@schematics/angular             16.2.3
rxjs                            7.5.7
typescript                      4.9.5
zone.js                         0.13.3
```


### Anything else?

I was able to work around this with a more forgiving regex, which however, is not actually correct to the format I really want to have. As the pipe manipulates the format, it is forgivable in this case, but one of my main issues with this is that it was very hard to find. My initial impression was that the implementation of the regex in the validator was buggy since the regex worked fine on regex101.com and regexr.com with my test input data, however, the "error" was in fact the order in which pipe and validator is run. 

I don't fully understand what you mean by "Is this a regression" so I might have answered it incorrectly.

Please don't suggest using the currencyPipe, it completely crapped the bed when setting it to SEK and the spaces used in swedish locale for thousand delimiters. The currencyPipe was my initial idea for this but I decided to abandon it because it just didn't work.

Issues.Title: File is not defined in a new project Angular 17
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug?

Don't known / other

### Is this a regression?

Yes

### Description

Create a new standalone projet with Angular 17 RC1 and simply declare a variable of type File :

```ts
import { CommonModule } from '@angular/common';
import { AfterViewInit, Component } from '@angular/core';
import { RouterOutlet } from '@angular/router';

@Component({
  selector: 'app-root',
  standalone: true,
  imports: [
    CommonModule,
    RouterOutlet
  ],
  templateUrl: './app.component.html',
  styleUrls: ['./app.component.scss']
})
export class AppComponent {
  title = 'test';
  test: File;

  constructor() {
    this.test = new File([''], 'test', { type: 'text/plain' });
  }
}
```

When executing:

```
File is not defined
    at new _AppComponent (/main.server.mjs:41:23)
    at NodeInjectorFactory.AppComponent_Factory [as factory] (/main.server.mjs:49:12)
    at getNodeInjectable (file:///F:/source/test/node_modules/@angular/core/fesm2022/core.mjs:4265:44)
    at createRootComponent (file:///F:/source/test/node_modules/@angular/core/fesm2022/core.mjs:14412:35)
    at ComponentFactory.create (file:///F:/source/test/node_modules/@angular/core/fesm2022/core.mjs:14276:25)
    at ApplicationRef.bootstrap (file:///F:/source/test/node_modules/@angular/core/fesm2022/core.mjs:31127:42)
    at file:///F:/source/test/node_modules/@angular/core/fesm2022/core.mjs:30649:32
    at _ZoneDelegate.invoke (F:\source\test\node_modules\zone.js\fesm2015\zone-node.js:368:26)
    at Object.onInvoke (file:///F:/source/test/node_modules/@angular/core/fesm2022/core.mjs:11190:33)
    at _ZoneDelegate.invoke (F:\source\test\node_modules\zone.js\fesm2015\zone-node.js:367:52
```

### Please provide a link to a minimal reproduction of the bug

_No response_

### Please provide the exception or error you saw

```true
File is not defined
    at new _AppComponent (/main.server.mjs:41:23)
    at NodeInjectorFactory.AppComponent_Factory [as factory] (/main.server.mjs:49:12)
    at getNodeInjectable (file:///F:/source/test/node_modules/@angular/core/fesm2022/core.mjs:4265:44)
```

Issues.Title: application builder: strange behavior of PLATFORM_ID
Issues.Body:
### Command

serve

### Is this a regression?

- [X] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

_No response_

### Description

Hi.
With enabled ssr, dev server starts to serve ssr-ed application. With this setup, PLATFORM_ID is always browser, while it actually runs in server environment.
This leads to non-working hydration because of setTimeout() calls, which must be called only in browser env.
How should i write browser-only or server-only logic now? What is the way?

Take a look at this example, which leads to hydration errors: 

```
constructor() {
    if(isPlatformServer(inject(PLATFORM_ID))) {
      return;
    }

    console.log('i am browser');

    setTimeout(() => console.log('hi from browser'), 11000);
  }
```

Issues.Title: fix(@schematics/angular): enable TypeScript `esModuleInterop` by default for ESM compliance
Issues.Body:
The `esModuleInterop` TypeScript option is a TypeScript recommended option that ensures that TypeScript emits compliant ESM code when transforming namespace and default imports. This is important for new projects because they now use the `application` builder which emits full ESM code. Not using this option with certain third-party packages can result in build warnings and the potential for runtime failure. For existing applications that are considering migrating, information pertaining to this situation will be available within the documentation.

Since the `allowSyntheticDefaultImports` is implied and automatically enabled when `esModuleInterop` is enabled, the previous option has been replaced with this one.

Reference: https://www.typescriptlang.org/tsconfig#esModuleInterop
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(@schematics/angular): enable TypeScript `esModuleInterop` by default for ESM compliance" (#26146)

Issues.Body: The newly introduced incremental bundler result caching is now used for both global styles (`styles` option) and global scripts (`scripts` option). ## What is the current behavior?

In v17.0.0-rc.1, `ng serve` might fail with: `Cannot read properties of undefined (reading 'explicit')` because `result.externalMetadata` is optional (see https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/blob/main/packages/angular_devkit/build_angular/src/tools/esbuild/bundler-execution-result.ts#L33)

Issues.Title: refactor(@angular-devkit/build-angular): prevent vite from resolving explicit external dependencies
Issues.Body: When using the Vite-based development server combined with the `externalDependencies` option, Vite will no longer attempt to resolve the explicitly marked externals. This is still not ideal since it Vite will still transform the import specifier to `/@id/${source}` but is currently closer to a raw external than a resolved file path. Further investigation with a possible feature request for Vite may be needed to achieve the desired outcome of an unresolved and untransformed external import specifier.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "refactor(@angular-devkit/build-angular): prevent vite from resolving explicit external dependencies" (#26129)

Issues.Title: fix(@angular-devkit/build-angular): avoid binary content in architect results with browser-esbuild
Issues.Body: The builder system (architect) currently attempts to treat all results as JSON and attempts to validate the object with a JSON schema validator. This can lead to slow build completion (even after the actual build is fully complete) or crashes if the size and/or quantity of output files is large. Architect only requires a `success` property so that is all that will be passed here if the infrastructure settings have not been explicitly set to avoid writes. Writing is only disabled when used directly by the dev server which bypasses the architect behavior.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "fix(@angular-devkit/build-angular): avoid binary content in architect results with browser-esbuild" (#26142)

### Command

### Description

`@angular-devkit/build-angular:browser-esbuild` builder is throwing css warning from third party packages

`@angular-devkit/build-angular:browser` is not throwing this warning

- go inside `angular.json` and update `builder` to `@angular-devkit/build-angular:browser-esbuild`. You will need to update `browser` to `main`

Issues.Title: Proxy Configuration Fails in Angular >=15 with Node >=17 When Targeting HTTPS Backends Due to OpenSSL 3 Restrictions
Issues.Body:
### Command

serve

### Is this a regression?

- [X] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

Angular 15 with Node 16

### Description

When working with Angular 15 and Node 18 in a local development environment, the proxy configuration in Angular CLI fails to function as expected when targeting HTTPS backends on different environments (development, pre-production, production). The underlying cause seems to be the shift to OpenSSL 3 in Node 17 and above, which restricts connections to remote endpoints using TLS versions lower than 1.3 due to security concerns.

### Minimal Reproduction

- Set up a local development environment with Angular 15 and Node 18.
- Configure the proxy settings in Angular CLI to point to a backend using HTTPS with TLS 1.2.
- Attempt to access the backend via the proxy from the local development environment.
- Observe the failure in proxy configuration, preventing access to the backend.

### Exception or Error

```text
[HPM] Error occurred while trying to proxy request ***** from localhost:4200 to https://*****.*** (EPROTO) (https://nodejs.org/api/errors.html#errors_common_system_errors).
```


### Your Environment

```text
Angular Version: 15
Node.js Version: 18

Backend TLS Version: 1.2
```


### Anything else relevant?

Backend TLS Version: 1.2

_Node >=17 uses: OpenSSL Version: 3_

This issue disrupts our development workflow significantly as the proxy configuration is crucial for pointing to different backends from the local environment. It appears that the restriction on TLS versions is a security feature implemented in OpenSSL 3, which prevents connections to less secure protocols.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Proxy Configuration Fails in Angular >=15 with Node >=17 When Targeting HTTPS Backends Due to OpenSSL 3 Restrictions" (#26134)

Issues.Title: feat(@angular-devkit/build-angular): add custom postcss plugin support
Issues.Body:
## PR Checklist

Please check to confirm your PR fulfills the following requirements:

<!-- Please check all that apply using "x". -->

- [ x] The commit message follows our guidelines: https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md#-commit-message-guidelines
- [ ] Tests for the changes have been added (for bug fixes / features)
- [ ] Docs have been added / updated (for bug fixes / features)

## PR Type

What kind of change does this PR introduce?

<!-- Please check the one that applies to this PR using "x". -->

- [ ] Bugfix
- [x ] Feature
- [ ] Code style update (formatting, local variables)
- [ ] Refactoring (no functional changes, no api changes)
- [ ] Build related changes
- [ ] CI related changes
- [ ] Documentation content changes
- [ ] Other... Please describe:

## What is the current behavior?

Currently including user PostCSS plugins into the Angular build process is not easily accomplished. This PR intends to fix that.

## What is the new behavior?

This commit adds seamless custom PostCSS plugin inclusion to the Angular build process, with minimal changes to the angular-cli source.
Adding a postcss plugin is now as easy as,

1) Installing the plugin package (e.g. ```npm install postcss-nested```)
2) Adding the package name to ```angular.json``` ```postcssPlugins```

    e.g.
```
        .
        .
        .
        "styles": [
          "src/styles.scss"
        ],
        "postcssPlugins": [
          {
            "packageName": "postcss-nested",
            "options": {
              "bubble": []
            }
          }
        ],
        .
        .
        .
```

## Does this PR introduce a breaking change?

- [ ] Yes
- [ x] No

<!-- If this PR contains a breaking change, please describe the impact and migration path for existing applications below. -->

## Other information

Issues.Title: feat(cdk/a11y): isFakeMousedownFromScreenReader - Layout thrashing (forced layout reflow)
Issues.Body:
### Feature Description

The current implementation of the isFakeMousedownFromScreenReader function results in [Layout thrashing / forced layout reflow](https://web.dev/articles/avoid-large-complex-layouts-and-layout-thrashing). This method is called by InputModalityDetector on every mouse down event. This causes performance issues when using virtually any component that uses InputModalityDetector (CdkMenuTrigger for example).

Layout thrashing is triggered by this line:
https://github.com/angular/components/blob/01a95013c6ae0b7bce31f74ec8e1d4afe3749cda/src/cdk/a11y/fake-event-detection.ts#L18C35-L18C35
Which is caused by using the offsetX and offsetY properties.

It would be good to find another solution to detect fake mousedown events (without usage of these properties).

### Use Case

_No response_
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "feat(cdk/a11y): isFakeMousedownFromScreenReader - Layout thrashing (forced layout reflow)" (#28010)

Issues.Title: refactor(material/button): handle disabled states through tokens
Issues.Body:
**This is a cherry-pick of #28005** to the RC branch.

MDC applies disabled styles through the `:disabled` selector which forced us to work around it by using a selector like `.mat-mdc-button[disabled][disabled]` and setting both the disabled and enabled button tokens. This is problematic, because it increases the specificity too much and it introduces space for mistakes, because we have to duplicate the tokens values.

These changes resolve the issue by re-applying the token slots to disabled buttons with the correct selector so that they can reuse the same tokens as the `button` nodes.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "refactor(material/button): handle disabled states through tokens" (#28007)

Issues.Title: refactor(material/button): handle disabled states through tokens
Issues.Body:
MDC applies disabled styles through the `:disabled` selector which forced us to work around it by using a selector like `.mat-mdc-button[disabled][disabled]` and setting both the disabled and enabled button tokens. This is problematic, because it increases the specificity too much and it introduces space for mistakes, because we have to duplicate the tokens values.

These changes resolve the issue by re-applying the token slots to disabled buttons with the correct selector so that they can reuse the same tokens as the `button` nodes.

Issues.Title: docs-bug(material design spec compliancy / compatibility): what process/system is used for this?
Issues.Body:
### Documentation Feedback

Hi,

A couple of questions came up in our team regarding Angular Material's compatibility and **parity** to material design specs.

We noticed that - for example - the `Expansion panel`, which was introduced in material design v1 (https://m1.material.io/components/expansion-panels.html#) still exists in the latest Angular Material version (https://material.angular.io/components/expansion/overview)

However, the expansion panel as a design component is not present in the material design v2 spec (except for list component expand-and-collapse: https://m2.material.io/components/lists#types no deeplink, search `expand and collapse`)

The first question is this:
Was it an explicit decision to keep supporting previous Material Design spec design components as opposed to dropping them and is this documented somewhere?

The second question is actually a followup question of the first: 
If it was [an explicit decision], is there some sort of deprecation policy for components that are phased out in future Material Design spec versions?

### Affected documentation page

https://material.angular.io/components/expansion/overview
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "docs-bug(material design spec compliancy / compatibility): what process/system is used for this?" (#28006)

Issues.Title: bug(Table): Tab navigation on inputs inside table with sticky columns (focus out of sight)
Issues.Body:
### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

_No response_

### Description

When having multiple inputs on one row, one input per cell, inside a table with one or more sticky columns the TAB key navigation is focusing at some point on an input that is hidden under the sticky columns, making the focus out of sight, but still inside the table.

The current behavior it's not compliant with the latest accessibility guidelines (WCAG) that states that an element that is focused needs to be in sight. (ref link: https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG22/Understanding/focus-not-obscured-minimum)

### Reproduction

StackBlitz link: 
https://stackblitz.com/edit/r22tvc?file=src%2Fexample%2Ftable-sticky-complex-flex-example.html

Table state:
 - have horizontal scroll (requires a higher number of columns)
 - one or more columns sticky
 - on at least one row have an input on each cell
 
Steps to reproduce:
1. Scroll the table in order to hide some columns under the sticky columns
2. Focus first inside the first cell of the row with the inputs
3. Press TAB key in order to navigate through the inputs
4. The focus at some point is on the input that is hidden under the sticky columns


### Expected Behavior

The focused element should be in sight, visible, not hidden under the sticky columns.

### Actual Behavior

The focus is hidden under the sticky columns, out of sight.

DEMO:
![table_TAB_focus](https://github.com/angular/components/assets/26005241/58a91a07-5b04-41c3-a54c-f1ccda6b9b8c)


### Environment

- Angular: 16.1.1
- CDK/Material: 16.2.9
- Browser(s): Chrome (118.0.5993.89) / Firefix (119.0)
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): Windows x64
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "bug(Table): Tab navigation on inputs inside table with sticky columns (focus out of sight)" (#28004)

Issues.Title: refactor(material/button): clean up fab tokens
Issues.Body:
Reworks the tokens setup for the FAB by:
* Introducing a custom tokens map. It was necessary both for these changes and will come in handy later for the ripples.
* Using tokens specifically for the disabled state instead of passing in the non-disabled ones. This aligns the FAB with the rest of the library and allows us to reduce the specificity.
* Introducing a tokens specifically for the icon/text color. Currently we have an ad-hoc variable declared directly in the component styles.
* Using our own mixins for the elevation instead of MDC's. Our mixin calls into MDC eventually, but it has some safeguards as well.
* Generating the tokens that we pass into MDC's theme using our APIs, instead of creating the map directly.

This issue is about when navigating to the select element a specific way, screen reader focus is lost when opening the popup menu. When linear navigating to the combobox element with VoiceOver, opening the popup causes screen reader focus to stay on the trigger

### Reproduction

Popup menu opens and focus is on the popup menu

Issues.Body: Reworks the component internals to use the new built-in control flow instead of `ngIf`, `ngSwitch` and `ngFor`. This has the advantage of not requiring directives to be imported and instantiated.
